Description: This video contains an explanation on the scientific method using "What type of music will make a plant grow best?" as an example. Start at 4:46 if you want to skip some of the historical background.
Learn about the difference between correlation and cause by looking at several headlines. Try to apply what you learn from this video to headlines that you see everyday.

Resource Name: Correlation vs. Causation: How to Tell the Difference (6:18)
Description: This video discusses the difference between correlation and causation, especially when applied to scoring websites. (Some of the examples in the video does reference HTML tags and other web programming terminology.)
Titles: Correlation vs. Causation: How to Tell the Difference

Description: An eye-opening video that illustrates how causality and correlation is not the same thing and how it's misconstrued to a large extent in health articles.

In this video a group of students design an experiment and test it. They follow the scientific method and show how to plan, execute, and record an experiment. They also account for things such as control groups and independent variables.
This video gives an overview of uniformitarianism and some of the key thinkers that contributed to the principle of uniformitarianism.

Resource Name: Mineral Characteristics - Hommocks Earth Science Department (7:55)
Description: This video gives an overview of the physical properties of minerals and shows different types of minerals that students can learn to associate with these properties.
Titles: Mineral Characteristics - Hommocks Earth Science Department

Description: This video provides a further description for some of the examples of mineral formation shown in the concept such as the formation of minerals through volcanic activity and the formation of the tufa towers at Mono Lake.
This video describes the Bowen's Reaction Series in great detail. (There is a tip on memorizing the discontinuous series at 2:15.)

Resource Name: How To Know About Igneous Rocks (1:50)
Description: This video explains what a rock is and what the difference between intrusive and extrusive igneous rocks is.
Titles: How To Know About Igneous Rocks

Description: This video gives a brief overview of what sedimentary rocks are and how they are formed. It also includes some vocab present in the chapter
Embed Code: <object width="640" height="382" classid="clsid:D27CDB6E-AE6D-11cf-96B8-444553540000" id="videojugplayer"><param name="movie" value="http://www.videojug.com/player?id=144843f6-f2b9-7249-d40b-ff0008ca4ddf"></param><param name="allowFullScreen" value="true"></param><param name="allowScriptAccess" value="always"></param><embed src="http://www.videojug.com/player?id=144843f6-f2b9-7249-d40b-ff0008ca4ddf" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" width="640" height="382" allowFullScreen="true" allowScriptAccess="always"></embed></object>

Description: This video explains how sedimentary rocks are created and is helpful to gain a deeper understanding of the topic.
This video describes what metamorphic rocks are and how they are made.
Embed Code: <object width="640" height="382" classid="clsid:D27CDB6E-AE6D-11cf-96B8-444553540000" id="videojugplayer"><param name="movie" value="http://www.videojug.com/player?id=a04e451f-83a8-14d7-8628-ff0008ca4de0"></param><param name="allowFullScreen" value="true"></param><param name="allowScriptAccess" value="always"></param><embed src="http://www.videojug.com/player?id=a04e451f-83a8-14d7-8628-ff0008ca4de0" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" width="640" height="382" allowFullScreen="true" allowScriptAccess="always"></embed></object>

Description: This video introduces P-waves and S-waves and their properties.
This video reviews how the continental drift hypothesis was formed and what it is in two minutes. It gives you a basic overview of the ideas formed by Wegener and the time period.
Embed Code: <iframe id="dit-video-embed" width="640" height="360" src="http://static.discoverymedia.com/videos/components/sci/a4dc2eb61bfe3c4e420f41ce0f9b6d10abe96653/snag-it-player.html?auto=no" frameborder="0" scrolling="no" allowtransparency="true"></iframe>

Authors: Dr. Kenneth Pickering; NASA Now Minute
Description: This upbeat video clearly explains the layers of the earth's atmosphere!
This interesting video talks about how the ozone layer in the stratosphere is formed and the impacts humans have on it.
A video showing how geothermal energy is processed and used.
This awesome video has the famous Bill Nye the Science Guy explaining what is pseudoscience and why it isn't a science.
A song that describes the scientific method. The lyrics to the song are shown in the video so that you can sing along!
A catchy, neat video that outlines the scientific method sung to the tune "Just A Dream" by Nelly. It is memorable and captures the attention of all audiences, young and old, scientist or not.

Resource Name: Questions No One Knows the Answer To (12:08)
Description: The video discusses topics that scientists are still exploring and opens your mind to new and interesting scientific questions. It explores different hypotheses and theories on the number of universes and why we can't detect alien life.
Titles: Questions No One Knows the Answer To

Description: A video that briefly illustrates plate movement and the theory of plate tectonics introduced in this concept.

Resource Name: Just How Small is an Atom? (5:28)
Description: In this animated video, Bergmann uses a series of analogies to truly represent how small an atom is and how small its nucleus is.
Titles: Just How Small is an Atom?

Description: This video shows in great detail how road salt is made. It gives an interesting and real world look at how minerals are extracted, processed, and commercialized.
This video talks about the formation of intrusive and extrusive igneous rocks and shows where they are found in different places in some parts of the world.
This is a video of a total eclipse from India.
In this video, watch how land masses on the Earth evolved over hundreds of millions of years, and see what it might look like in the future.

Resource Name: NASA SCI Files - Fossils and Plate Tectonics (4:37)
Description: This video shows the causes for moving landmasses. It also briefly mentions how the continental drift has affected the location of fossils and rocks.
Titles: NASA SCI Files - Fossils and Plate Tectonics

Description: In this video, Bill Nye explains how seafloor spreading was discovered and the role seafloor spreading played in the development of the theory of plate tectonics.
Embed Code: <iframe id="dit-video-embed" width="640" height="360" src="http://static.discoverymedia.com/videos/components/sci/a4dc2eb61bfe3c4e420f41ce0f9b6d10abe96653/snag-it-player.html?auto=no" frameborder="0" scrolling="no" allowtransparency="true"></iframe>

Description: This site features two videos, the first of which reviews Earth's tectonic plates, as well as Earth's layers. The second video talks about the way Earth's tectonic plates affect humans around the world!

Resource Name: Predicting Earthquakes: Seismic Hazards in Haiti and California (3:27)
Description: This video talks about how a team of scientists warned that a large earthquake could hit Haiti in 2008 and how the Bay Area in California could be next.
Titles: Predicting Earthquakes: Seismic Hazards in Haiti and California

Resource Name: New Dramatic Video: Tsunami Wave Spills over Seawall, Smashes Boats, Cars (1:59)
Description: A video of the Japanese tsunami of 2011 hitting the town of Miyako illustrates the destructive power of tsunamis.
Titles: New Dramatic Video: Tsunami Wave Spills over Seawall, Smashes Boats, Cars

Description: This Bill Nye the Science Guy video looks at the Earth's crust and its layers. Connections are also made to volcanoes and plate tectonics.
The video on this website shows footage of some of the damage in Japan after the 2011 Tohoku earthquake and is a grim reminder of the importance of earthquake safety.
This video shows an earthquake safe building and how that building was constructed.

Resource Name: What is LA's Most Earthquake-Proof Building? (2:47)
Description: This engaging video shows LA's most innovative and earthquake-safe building and tells you why it is so well suited to surviving an earthquake.
Titles: What is LA's Most Earthquake-Proof Building?

Resource Name: Hawaiian Hot Spots: Undersea Volcanic Studies (3:03)
Description: This video shows the Hawaiian islands and explains how they were formed by hotspots. (Start at 0:26 if you want to skip the introductory scenic footage.)
Titles: Hawaiian Hot Spots: Undersea Volcanic Studies

Description: A very brief video that describes the three types of volcanoes. (Good for a quick review.) Note that shield volcano is misspelled as "sheild" in the video.

Resource Name: Scenario: Supervolcano Eruption in the US (2:22)
Description: This interesting video illustrates the magnitude and consequences of a supervolcano eruption.
Titles: Scenario: Supervolcano Eruption in the US

Description: This short but exciting video illustrates how land masses and mountains were formed by Hawaiian volcanoes.
Embed Code: <object width="480" height="340"><param name="movie" value="http://www.history.com/flash/VideoPlayer.swf?vid=4186786401"></param><param name="allowScriptAccess" value="always"></param><param name="allowFullScreen" value="true"></param><embed src="http://www.history.com/flash/VideoPlayer.swf?vid=4186786401" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" allowfullscreen="true" allowScriptAccess="always" width="480" height="340"></embed></object>

Description: This link contains a cool slideshow of interesting and surprising natural structures that were formed by glaciers.

Resource Name: The Real Danger Lurking in the Water (17:18)
Description: This video contains an incredible talk about the dangers of polluting rivers and all the other ecosystems of the world, as well as the impacts that has on not only animals, but also humans.

Titles: The Real Danger Lurking in the Water

Description: This short but intense video illustrates the beauty of icebergs and sparks the idea that we need to do something to keep these and glaciers from disappearing.

Description: This is an engaging, short video about the resources the ocean can provide and also focuses on how we can draw on those resources in an environmentally friendly way.

Description: This video uses models to demonstrate the affect that salt has on water and how it affects the different trophic levels

Resource Name: The Deep Sea - Exploring the Zones (5:54)
Description: This video shows people exploring different ocean zones in the deep sea through a submarine that they rigged up.
Titles: The Deep Sea - Exploring the Zones

Description: See how the moon rotates around the Earth and effects the tides of the ocean through a fun animation.

Resource Name: How a Hurricane is Born - The Science Of Superstorms (2:29)
Description: This video explains the fascinating story of how a hurricane is created.
Titles: How a Hurricane is Born - The Science Of Superstorms

Resource Name: Symbiosis: A Surprising Tale of Species Cooperation (2:23)
Description: This is an interesting video going into more depth about symbiosis and how it applies to a real ecosystem.
Titles: Symbiosis: A Surprising Tale of Species Cooperation

Description: The video at this link describes the individual steps of the nitrogen cycle and how they differ when different kinds of fertilizers are added to soil.
This video shows footage from the bottom of the ocean where volcanoes cause hydrothermal vents. The video also describes some of the amazing organisms that thrive near the vents.

Resource Name: Planetary Formation: James Webb Space Telescope Science (3:21)
Description: This video describes the best ideas astronomers have about the events before the formation of stars and planets.
Titles: Planetary Formation: James Webb Space Telescope Science

Resource Name: Naked Science : Birth of the Solar System (2:55)
Description: This video describes the birth of the solar system.
Titles: Naked Science : Birth of the Solar System

Resource Name: The Missing Link to Renewable Energy (15:15)
Description: A part of obtaining energy resources is being able to store the energy until we're ready to use it. In this video, Donald Sadoway talks about the first liquid grid-based battery.
Titles: The Missing Link to Renewable Energy

Resource Name: Making A Top Energy Efficient Home (5:54)
Description: This video is about the energy efficiency part of the concept. It shows how some contractors have built an extremely energy efficient home. Efficient buildings waste less energy, last longer, and ultimately cost much less than inefficient buildings.
Titles: Making A Top Energy Efficient Home

Description: A video that describes the change in public attitudes that has been driven by improving renewable energy technology.

Resource Name: Evaluating World Oil Reserves: How Much Is Left? (8:32)
Description: In this video, leading industry analysts estimate the amount of oil left and the implication of those numbers for the global economy and energy resources
Titles: Evaluating World Oil Reserves: How Much Is Left?

Description: In this video, Kirk Sorensen tells us a little bit about a new, enticing form of generating nuclear power: using fluoride salts for cooling instead of water and replacing uranium with thorium.
In this video, Steven Cowley explains how the future of energy has to be nuclear fusion.

Description: A short clip on one of the most attractive renewable energies: solar power.

Description: This video explores harnessing the power of ocean waves.
In this video, William Kamkwamba talks about how he built a windmill to power his family's home at age 14. He shares how he built the windmill using plans in a library book and spare parts and scrap.

Description: The 6-minute documentary at this link describes the wind turbine business.
A video that talks about how the economy could be structured more efficiently to reduce waste and pollution.

Resource Name: How to Make Filthy Water Drinkable (9:29)
Description: Engineer Michael Pritchard talks about inventing the portable Lifesaver filter, which can make the most revolting water drinkable in seconds. See the demonstration of this incredible invention in this video!
Embed Code: <object width="526" height="374"><param name="movie" value="http://video.ted.com/assets/player/swf/EmbedPlayer.swf"></param><param name="allowFullScreen" value="true" /><param name="allowScriptAccess" value="always"/><param name="wmode" value="transparent"></param><param name="bgColor" value="#ffffff"></param><param name="flashvars" value="vu=http://video.ted.com/talk/stream/2009G/Blank/MichaelPritchard_2009G-320k.mp4&su=http://images.ted.com/images/ted/tedindex/embed-posters/MichaelPritchard-2009G.embed_thumbnail.jpg&vw=512&vh=288&ap=0&ti=613&lang=en&introDuration=15330&adDuration=4000&postAdDuration=830&adKeys=talk=michael_pritchard_invents_a_water_filter;year=2009;theme=tales_of_invention;theme=design_like_you_give_a_damn;event=TEDGlobal+2009;tag=business;tag=demo;tag=design;tag=global+issues;tag=invention;tag=technology;tag=water;&preAdTag=tconf.ted/embed;tile=1;sz=512x288;" /><embed src="http://video.ted.com/assets/player/swf/EmbedPlayer.swf" pluginspace="http://www.macromedia.com/go/getflashplayer" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" wmode="transparent" bgColor="#ffffff" width="526" height="374" allowFullScreen="true" allowScriptAccess="always" flashvars="vu=http://video.ted.com/talk/stream/2009G/Blank/MichaelPritchard_2009G-320k.mp4&su=http://images.ted.com/images/ted/tedindex/embed-posters/MichaelPritchard-2009G.embed_thumbnail.jpg&vw=512&vh=288&ap=0&ti=613&lang=en&introDuration=15330&adDuration=4000&postAdDuration=830&adKeys=talk=michael_pritchard_invents_a_water_filter;year=2009;theme=tales_of_invention;theme=design_like_you_give_a_damn;event=TEDGlobal+2009;tag=business;tag=demo;tag=design;tag=global+issues;tag=invention;tag=technology;tag=water;&preAdTag=tconf.ted/embed;tile=1;sz=512x288;"></embed></object>
Titles: How to Make Filthy Water Drinkable

Description: In this video, coral reef ecologist Jeremy Jackson discusses the pathetic state of the ocean today, with indicators that things will get much worse. Jackson employs shocking photos and statistics to convince viewers of the gravity of the situation.
Embed Code: <object width="526" height="374"><param name="movie" value="http://video.ted.com/assets/player/swf/EmbedPlayer.swf"></param><param name="allowFullScreen" value="true" /><param name="allowScriptAccess" value="always"/><param name="wmode" value="transparent"></param><param name="bgColor" value="#ffffff"></param><param name="flashvars" value="vu=http://video.ted.com/talk/stream/2010Z/Blank/JeremyJackson_2010Z-320k.mp4&su=http://images.ted.com/images/ted/tedindex/embed-posters/JeremyJackson-2010Z.embed_thumbnail.jpg&vw=512&vh=288&ap=0&ti=850&lang=en&introDuration=15330&adDuration=4000&postAdDuration=830&adKeys=talk=jeremy_jackson;year=2010;theme=inspired_by_nature;theme=a_taste_of_mission_blue_voyage;theme=ocean_stories;theme=bold_predictions_stern_warnings;event=Mission+Blue+Voyage;tag=fish;tag=green;tag=mission+blue;tag=oceans;tag=science;&preAdTag=tconf.ted/embed;tile=1;sz=512x288;" /><embed src="http://video.ted.com/assets/player/swf/EmbedPlayer.swf" pluginspace="http://www.macromedia.com/go/getflashplayer" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" wmode="transparent" bgColor="#ffffff" width="526" height="374" allowFullScreen="true" allowScriptAccess="always" flashvars="vu=http://video.ted.com/talk/stream/2010Z/Blank/JeremyJackson_2010Z-320k.mp4&su=http://images.ted.com/images/ted/tedindex/embed-posters/JeremyJackson-2010Z.embed_thumbnail.jpg&vw=512&vh=288&ap=0&ti=850&lang=en&introDuration=15330&adDuration=4000&postAdDuration=830&adKeys=talk=jeremy_jackson;year=2010;theme=inspired_by_nature;theme=a_taste_of_mission_blue_voyage;theme=ocean_stories;theme=bold_predictions_stern_warnings;event=Mission+Blue+Voyage;tag=fish;tag=green;tag=mission+blue;tag=oceans;tag=science;&preAdTag=tconf.ted/embed;tile=1;sz=512x288;"></embed></object>

Description: This video describes the formation of the Texas-sized Great Pacific Garbage and the damage it wrecks on marine organisms living in the area.

Resource Name: Captain Charles Moore on the Seas of Plastic (7:24)
Description: In this video, Moore discusses the devastating effects of pollution in the ocean and shows shocking pictures of miles and miles of trash floating in the ocean.
Titles: Captain Charles Moore on the Seas of Plastic

Resource Name: The Oil Spill's Unseen Culprits, Victims (19:56)
Description: This video looks at the impact of the Gulf oil spill on organisms in the Gulf.
Embed Code: <object width="526" height="374"><param name="movie" value="http://video.ted.com/assets/player/swf/EmbedPlayer.swf"></param><param name="allowFullScreen" value="true" /><param name="allowScriptAccess" value="always"/><param name="wmode" value="transparent"></param><param name="bgColor" value="#ffffff"></param><param name="flashvars" value="vu=http://video.ted.com/talk/stream/2010X/Blank/CarlSafina_2010X-320k.mp4&su=http://images.ted.com/images/ted/tedindex/embed-posters/CarlSafina-2010X.embed_thumbnail.jpg&vw=512&vh=288&ap=0&ti=914&lang=en&introDuration=15330&adDuration=4000&postAdDuration=830&adKeys=talk=carl_safina_the_oil_spill_s_unseen_culprits_victims;year=2010;theme=ocean_stories;theme=bold_predictions_stern_warnings;theme=animals_that_amaze;event=TEDxOilSpill;tag=disaster+relief;tag=energy;tag=environment;tag=oceans;tag=oil;tag=pollution;&preAdTag=tconf.ted/embed;tile=1;sz=512x288;" /><embed src="http://video.ted.com/assets/player/swf/EmbedPlayer.swf" pluginspace="http://www.macromedia.com/go/getflashplayer" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" wmode="transparent" bgColor="#ffffff" width="526" height="374" allowFullScreen="true" allowScriptAccess="always" flashvars="vu=http://video.ted.com/talk/stream/2010X/Blank/CarlSafina_2010X-320k.mp4&su=http://images.ted.com/images/ted/tedindex/embed-posters/CarlSafina-2010X.embed_thumbnail.jpg&vw=512&vh=288&ap=0&ti=914&lang=en&introDuration=15330&adDuration=4000&postAdDuration=830&adKeys=talk=carl_safina_the_oil_spill_s_unseen_culprits_victims;year=2010;theme=ocean_stories;theme=bold_predictions_stern_warnings;theme=animals_that_amaze;event=TEDxOilSpill;tag=disaster+relief;tag=energy;tag=environment;tag=oceans;tag=oil;tag=pollution;&preAdTag=tconf.ted/embed;tile=1;sz=512x288;"></embed></object>
Titles: The Oil Spill's Unseen Culprits, Victims

Resource Name: A Novel Idea for Cleaning Up Oil Spills (14:30)
Description: In this video, Cesar Harada talks about how he designed a boat that may one day be able to clean up oil spills.
Embed Code: <object width="526" height="374"><param name="movie" value="http://video.ted.com/assets/player/swf/EmbedPlayer.swf"></param><param name="allowFullScreen" value="true" /><param name="allowScriptAccess" value="always"/><param name="wmode" value="transparent"></param><param name="bgColor" value="#ffffff"></param><param name="flashvars" value="vu=http://video.ted.com/talk/stream/2012S/Blank/CesarHarada_2012S-320k.mp4&su=http://images.ted.com/images/ted/tedindex/embed-posters/CesarHarada_2012S-embed.jpg&vw=512&vh=288&ap=0&ti=1499&lang=en&introDuration=15330&adDuration=4000&postAdDuration=830&adKeys=talk=cesar_harada_a_novel_idea_for_cleaning_up_oil_spills;year=2012;theme=inspired_by_nature;theme=talks_from_ted_fellows;theme=ocean_stories;theme=a_greener_future;event=TEDxSummit;tag=global+issues;tag=oceans;tag=open-source;&preAdTag=tconf.ted/embed;tile=1;sz=512x288;" /><embed src="http://video.ted.com/assets/player/swf/EmbedPlayer.swf" pluginspace="http://www.macromedia.com/go/getflashplayer" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" wmode="transparent" bgColor="#ffffff" width="526" height="374" allowFullScreen="true" allowScriptAccess="always" flashvars="vu=http://video.ted.com/talk/stream/2012S/Blank/CesarHarada_2012S-320k.mp4&su=http://images.ted.com/images/ted/tedindex/embed-posters/CesarHarada_2012S-embed.jpg&vw=512&vh=288&ap=0&ti=1499&lang=en&introDuration=15330&adDuration=4000&postAdDuration=830&adKeys=talk=cesar_harada_a_novel_idea_for_cleaning_up_oil_spills;year=2012;theme=inspired_by_nature;theme=talks_from_ted_fellows;theme=ocean_stories;theme=a_greener_future;event=TEDxSummit;tag=global+issues;tag=oceans;tag=open-source;&preAdTag=tconf.ted/embed;tile=1;sz=512x288;"></embed></object>

Description: This is an intriguing and touching video about the consequences of continued global warming as the ice caps melt.
Embed Code: <object width="526" height="374"><param name="movie" value="http://video.ted.com/assets/player/swf/EmbedPlayer.swf"></param><param name="allowFullScreen" value="true" /><param name="allowScriptAccess" value="always"/><param name="wmode" value="transparent"></param><param name="bgColor" value="#ffffff"></param><param name="flashvars" value="vu=http://video.ted.com/talk/stream/2011/Blank/PaulNicklen_2011-320k.mp4&su=http://images.ted.com/images/ted/tedindex/embed-posters/PaulNicklen-2011.embed_thumbnail.jpg&vw=512&vh=288&ap=0&ti=1141&lang=en&introDuration=15330&adDuration=4000&postAdDuration=830&adKeys=talk=paul_nicklen_tales_of_ice_bound_wonderlands;year=2011;theme=animals_that_amaze;event=TED2011;tag=animals;tag=biodiversity;tag=creativity;tag=culture;tag=design;tag=entertainment;tag=photography;tag=storytelling;&preAdTag=tconf.ted/embed;tile=1;sz=512x288;" /><embed src="http://video.ted.com/assets/player/swf/EmbedPlayer.swf" pluginspace="http://www.macromedia.com/go/getflashplayer" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" wmode="transparent" bgColor="#ffffff" width="526" height="374" allowFullScreen="true" allowScriptAccess="always" flashvars="vu=http://video.ted.com/talk/stream/2011/Blank/PaulNicklen_2011-320k.mp4&su=http://images.ted.com/images/ted/tedindex/embed-posters/PaulNicklen-2011.embed_thumbnail.jpg&vw=512&vh=288&ap=0&ti=1141&lang=en&introDuration=15330&adDuration=4000&postAdDuration=830&adKeys=talk=paul_nicklen_tales_of_ice_bound_wonderlands;year=2011;theme=animals_that_amaze;event=TED2011;tag=animals;tag=biodiversity;tag=creativity;tag=culture;tag=design;tag=entertainment;tag=photography;tag=storytelling;&preAdTag=tconf.ted/embed;tile=1;sz=512x288;"></embed></object>

Description: This video contains a fun song talks about the characteristics of the sun.
A Video on solar storms.

Resource Name: Tour the solar system from home (7:53)
Description: In this video, Jon Nguyen demos NASA JPL's "Eyes on the Solar System", a free software that allows users to explore the planets, moons, asteroids, and spacecraft that rotate around our sun in real-time.
Titles: Tour the solar system from home

Resource Name: NASA | SDO's Ultra-high Definition View of 2012 Venus Transit (3:07)
Description: Video of the 2012 Venus transit across the sun. We can see Venus as a black disk against the sun. This event is one of the rarest predictable solar event.
Titles: NASA | SDO's Ultra-high Definition View of 2012 Venus Transit

Description: Video of the geological history of the moon.
The educational video on this site explains some basic information about Mars.

Resource Name: Could a Saturn Moon Harbor Life? (3:27)
Description: This is an interesting video on the chemical composition of one of Saturn's moons and how that suggests the presence of liquid water and other life-supporting compounds.
Embed Code: <object width="526" height="374"><param name="movie" value="http://video.ted.com/assets/player/swf/EmbedPlayer.swf"></param><param name="allowFullScreen" value="true" /><param name="allowScriptAccess" value="always"/><param name="wmode" value="transparent"></param><param name="bgColor" value="#ffffff"></param><param name="flashvars" value="vu=http://video.ted.com/talk/stream/2009U/Blank/CarolynPorco_2009U-320k.mp4&su=http://images.ted.com/images/ted/tedindex/embed-posters/CarolynPorco-2009U.embed_thumbnail.jpg&vw=512&vh=288&ap=0&ti=551&lang=en&introDuration=15330&adDuration=4000&postAdDuration=830&adKeys=talk=carolyn_porco_could_a_saturn_moon_harbor_life;year=2009;theme=technology_history_and_destiny;theme=to_boldly_go;theme=peering_into_space;event=TED2009;tag=astronomy;tag=exploration;tag=life;tag=science;tag=space;tag=technology;&preAdTag=tconf.ted/embed;tile=1;sz=512x288;" /><embed src="http://video.ted.com/assets/player/swf/EmbedPlayer.swf" pluginspace="http://www.macromedia.com/go/getflashplayer" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" wmode="transparent" bgColor="#ffffff" width="526" height="374" allowFullScreen="true" allowScriptAccess="always" flashvars="vu=http://video.ted.com/talk/stream/2009U/Blank/CarolynPorco_2009U-320k.mp4&su=http://images.ted.com/images/ted/tedindex/embed-posters/CarolynPorco-2009U.embed_thumbnail.jpg&vw=512&vh=288&ap=0&ti=551&lang=en&introDuration=15330&adDuration=4000&postAdDuration=830&adKeys=talk=carolyn_porco_could_a_saturn_moon_harbor_life;year=2009;theme=technology_history_and_destiny;theme=to_boldly_go;theme=peering_into_space;event=TED2009;tag=astronomy;tag=exploration;tag=life;tag=science;tag=space;tag=technology;&preAdTag=tconf.ted/embed;tile=1;sz=512x288;"></embed></object>
Titles: Could a Saturn Moon Harbor Life?

Resource Name: How We Found Hundreds of Potential Earth-Like Planets (18:30)
Description: This is a fascinating video about potential life on planets outside of our solar system. Start at 8:00 if you want to skip some less important background info!
Embed Code: <object width="526" height="374"><param name="movie" value="http://video.ted.com/assets/player/swf/EmbedPlayer.swf"></param><param name="allowFullScreen" value="true" /><param name="allowScriptAccess" value="always"/><param name="wmode" value="transparent"></param><param name="bgColor" value="#ffffff"></param><param name="flashvars" value="vu=http://video.ted.com/talk/stream/2010G/Blank/DimitarSasselov_2010G-320k.mp4&su=http://images.ted.com/images/ted/tedindex/embed-posters/DimitarSasselov-2010G.embed_thumbnail.jpg&vw=512&vh=288&ap=0&ti=920&lang=en&introDuration=15330&adDuration=4000&postAdDuration=830&adKeys=talk=dimitar_sasselov_how_we_found_hundreds_of_potential_ear;year=2010;theme=peering_into_space;event=TEDGlobal+2010;tag=astronomy;tag=biology;tag=life;tag=technology;tag=universe;&preAdTag=tconf.ted/embed;tile=1;sz=512x288;" /><embed src="http://video.ted.com/assets/player/swf/EmbedPlayer.swf" pluginspace="http://www.macromedia.com/go/getflashplayer" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" wmode="transparent" bgColor="#ffffff" width="526" height="374" allowFullScreen="true" allowScriptAccess="always" flashvars="vu=http://video.ted.com/talk/stream/2010G/Blank/DimitarSasselov_2010G-320k.mp4&su=http://images.ted.com/images/ted/tedindex/embed-posters/DimitarSasselov-2010G.embed_thumbnail.jpg&vw=512&vh=288&ap=0&ti=920&lang=en&introDuration=15330&adDuration=4000&postAdDuration=830&adKeys=talk=dimitar_sasselov_how_we_found_hundreds_of_potential_ear;year=2010;theme=peering_into_space;event=TEDGlobal+2010;tag=astronomy;tag=biology;tag=life;tag=technology;tag=universe;&preAdTag=tconf.ted/embed;tile=1;sz=512x288;"></embed></object>
Titles: How We Found Hundreds of Potential Earth-Like Planets

Description: One of the world's most famous astrophysicists describes what would happen if we were to get sucked into a black hole.
This video illustrates the role of gravity from black holes in solar systems.
Embed Code: <iframe id="dit-video-embed" width="640" height="360" src="http://static.discoverymedia.com/videos/components/dsc/514b0d907808535044b1f4d8a22f9a148ac6b31c/snag-it-player.html?auto=no" frameborder="0" scrolling="no" allowtransparency="true"></iframe>

Resource Name: NASA | Take a "Swift" Tour of the Andromeda Galaxy (3:06)
Description: This a video tour of the Andromeda Galaxy (M31).  It is a spiral galaxy much like our own Milky Way Galaxy.
Titles: NASA | Take a "Swift" Tour of the Andromeda Galaxy

Description: A video showing the scale of the universe. (Start at 0:28 if you want to skip opening credits.)
A video explaining the Big Bang and its significance
Patricia Burchat talks of dark matter and dark energy that comprises 96% of the universe in this video.

This activity takes you back to a sea voyage in 1759, long before the creation of GPS devices. Using the information given, can you figure out exactly where you are? Be sure to also explore how modern GPS systems work through the link provided.
Explore the three tabs below, titled "How the Crew Lives," "How It Works," and "ISS 360 Tour" to learn about space shuttles and what it is like to be an astronaut.
This quiz asks questions about minerals and their groups. It covers some material only touched upon in the concept so it encourages outside research.
This is an interesting interactive that allows you to explore all of the steps of the rock cycle in greater depth. Make sure to click on all the stages to view an animation!

Resource Name: Pictures of Intrusive and Extrusive Rock Types
Description: This gallery supplies images of many types of igneous rocks and lists their characteristics. It can help students recognize the different properties and see both intrusive and extrusive igneous rocks.

Authors: Ben Mierement; Tom Grace; Matthew Nyman; NOAA; TERC
Description: The link shows an animation of how the sedimentary rock is formed.
This animation helps to visualize all of the stages in sedimentary rock formation over time.

Authors: Matthew Nyman; TERC; Lenni Armstrong; informmotion
Description: This link shows you an animation of the formation of metamorphic rocks.
Test your understanding of the Coriolis effect with this game. Try to pick the right path for your plane to land on an airplane carrier by keeping the Coriolis effect in mind.
Piece together Earth's tectonic plates like a puzzle!
Choose different locations on the seafloor to find out the age of the crust there! Using your knowledge about the age of the Earth's crust, find out more information about the plates!

There are a couple of good illustrations and animations of the different plate boundaries. Scroll down to the bottom of the page to take a quiz on identifying the plates of the world and how they converge.
For information about a real endangered lake, visit this article on India's lakes by Time magazine.
This interactive looks at the causes of tides with a series of animated illustrations.
Quiz with ten multiple choice questions about the Troposphere that reviews the concept and stretches students to learn more!

This interactive map of the Earth's atmosphere gives information about the temperature and air pressure in each layer. There are also blurbs about each section if you click on them, as well as sample objects that might be found in each layer.
Identify different elements of a biological community and see their roles in real life.
See how energy cycles its way through the food chain.
Investigate the levels of four different food webs.
Follow the process of nitrogen fixation and see how it happens in nature.
Review the stages and contributing factors of the nitrogen cycle through an animation.
This interactive explores what early humans were like by examining Lucy's skeleton.

Resource Name: Biodiversity in the Rainforest: Welcome to the Dzanga-Sangha
Description: Explore the diverse relationships between organisms living in forests, bais (marshy clearing), and rivers of the Central African Republic.

This interactive allows you to design planets varies the type of star they orbit, their orbit size, mass, and existence of volcanoes, plate tectonics, water and producers with the goal of creating a planet that could support human life. By playing around with it, it teaches you the importance of each one and the effect it has on the planet.
This interactive site goes in-depth on how wind turbines work and what factors make these turbines effective
This interactive simulation demonstrates different steps of the water cycle, focusing on groundwater.
Explore the effects of greenhouse gases and how they trap heat molecules in a fun way.

Authors: NASA; JPL; California Institute of Technology
Description: Watch planets and other objects in the solar system move in real-time. You can also rewind back up to 1950 and forward to 2050 to see how they will move in the future. (Watch the introductory video if you need help.)
This is an interesting interactive that introduces you to some of the characteristics of Mercury's surface.

Resource Name: Keeping an Eye on Space Rocks
Description: This interesting website allows you to explore asteroids, comets, and meteors and their relationship to earth. Make sure you check out the size matters tab on the bottom!

Authors: The University of Texas McDonald Observatory
Description: This interesting website allows you to explore many different constellations and how they got their names, the main stars within them, and where they are located in the universe.
This interactive lets you explore the Milky Way from the Earth's perspective. Make sure to click the info button at the bottom for more information!
This site has great images and information about objects in our solar system and beyond.
This interesting website explores the universe and its development and expansion. There are many cool videos under Models of Expansion on the second page.
This simulation explores the relationship between the sun, moon and earth and how they orbit.
Embed Code: Click to Run

Description: This simulation looks at how the tilt (inclination angle in the simulation) affect the average daily temperature, the sunlight angle, and the length of day. Explore all the tabs to get the most out of this simulation.
A simulation that demonstrates how the sedimentary rock filters into layers as it falls.
This interactive allows you to change the wind speed and water depth to see how the ocean waves change.
This simulation shows how the amount of dark matter can affect orbital speed. It explains how scientists use this, and also includes some sample problems with solutions.
